newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asian dollar deposits quietly steady in late trade.
newsitem.headline: Asian dollar deposits quietly steady in late trade.

text.p: Asian dollar deposit rates were quietly steady in lacklustre trade with most traders sidelined ahead of the first leg of the U.S. treasury's quarterly refunding package, dealers said on Tuesday.

The treasury will offer the market US$39.75 billion at its refunding auction package this week. The sale will be made up of $17.75 billion in three year notes on Tuesday, $12.0 billion in 10-year notes on Wednesday and $10.0 billion in 30-year bonds on Thursday.
"Rates were steady to easier in the morning on some position adjustments," a local dealer said.
"The market moved with narrow range trading today ahead of the outcome of demand for tonight's auction of the three-year notes," he said.
In day-to-day rates, Tuesday/Wednesday, Wednesday/Thursday and week-fixed were unchanged from last Thursday's common 5-3/8 5-1/4 percent, respectively.

Among longer dates, one-month was unchanged at 5-7/16 5-5/16 percent, three-months eased 1/16 percentage point to 5-1/2 5-3/8, nine-months eased 1/16 point to 5-11/16 5-9/16 and twelve-months eased 1/16 point to 5-13/16 5-11/16 percent.
